dimensions.name: Concept Clarity
dimensions.description: How clearly the teacher explains core Java concepts such as OOP principles, data types, and memory management.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Uses simple definitions; illustrates abstract concepts with concrete Java code snippets and real‑world analogies.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Provides vague or confusing explanations; jumps between topics without linking them to Java syntax or semantics.

dimensions.name: Delivery & Communication
dimensions.description: Voice clarity, pacing, energy, and ability to keep learners focused during live coding sessions.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Clear voice, varied tone, steady pace; pauses to let students follow code execution; uses screen annotations effectively.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Monotone voice, speaks too fast or too slowly; excessive filler words; fails to highlight important parts of the code.

dimensions.name: Content Structure
dimensions.description: Logical flow of lessons: introduction → concept explanation → coding example → walkthrough → summary and key takeaways.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Starts with learning objectives, builds up from basic syntax to advanced features, uses smooth transitions between sections.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Random jumping between topics; no clear sequence; omits summaries or recap of important Java constructs.

dimensions.name: Student Engagement
dimensions.description: Interaction with learners through questions, live coding challenges, and debugging exercises specific to Java.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Asks probing questions about class design, encourages students to predict output, conducts pair‑programming or debugging drills.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: One‑way lecture with no checks for understanding; never invites students to write or modify Java code.

dimensions.name: Accuracy
dimensions.description: Correctness of Java language details, APIs, and best‑practice recommendations delivered during instruction.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: No factual mistakes; uses up‑to‑date Java versions; correctly explains exception handling, generics, and concurrency constructs.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Incorrect syntax, outdated API usage, wrong explanations of memory model or thread safety.
